main.title: About The Indian Space Research Organisation (ISRO)
main.html:
ISRO is the national space agency of India, headquartered in Bengaluru. It operates under the Department of Space (DOS), which is directly overseen by the Prime Minister of India.

ISRO is one of the world's leading space agencies, known for its cost-effective missions and significant achievements in space exploration, including the Mars Orbiter Mission (Mangalyaan) and Chandrayaan missions to the Moon.

howToJoin.title: How to Join ISRO
howToJoin.html: There are multiple pathways to join ISRO depending on your qualifications. Here are the primary entry points:

icrb.title: ISRO Centralised Recruitment Board (ICRB)
icrb.html:
A Beginner's Guide to the ISRO Scientist/Engineer 'SC' Exam (ICRB)

The ISRO Centralised Recruitment Board (ICRB), under the Department of Space, Government of India, is responsible for recruiting scientists and engineers.

1. Introduction: Your Journey to Becoming an ISRO Scientist

If you're dreaming of a career that lets you reach for the stars, you're in the right place. The Indian Space Research Organization (ISRO) regularly recruits bright engineering graduates for the prestigious post of Scientist/Engineer 'SC'. This is a Group ‚ÄòA‚Äô Gazetted post, equivalent to a Class-I officer. This guide will break down the entire process based on the latest advertisement (e.g., No. ISRO:ICRB:02(EMC):2025).

2. Are You Eligible? Checking the Boxes ‚úÖ

Educational Qualification

  • Degree: You need a B.E./B.Tech or an equivalent degree in one of the specified disciplines.
  • Disciplines: Electronics & Communication, Mechanical Engineering, or Computer Science Engineering.
  • Minimum Marks: You must have an aggregate minimum of 65% marks or a CGPA of 6.84/10.
  • Important Note: ISRO is very strict about this. If your university provides both percentage and CGPA, you must meet at least one of these criteria. You cannot convert your CGPA to a percentage to meet the eligibility.

Age Limit

  • The maximum age is 28 years as of the specified cut-off date (e.g., June 16, 2025).
  • Age relaxation is available for categories like Ex-Servicemen and Persons with Benchmark Disabilities (PwBD).

Nationality

You must be an Indian citizen.

3. The Application Process: How to Apply ‚úçÔ∏è

Applications are accepted online through the official ISRO website. Keep an eye on the ISRO Careers page for the latest advertisements.

Application Fee

There is a non-refundable application fee of ‚Çπ250. However, all female candidates, Scheduled Castes (SC), Scheduled Tribes (ST), Ex-servicemen, and Persons with Benchmark Disabilities (PwBD) are exempted from the fee.

4. The Selection Process: What to Expect üéØ

The selection process consists of two main stages:

Stage 1: Written Test

  • The test is conducted in two parts: Part ‚ÄòA‚Äô (Discipline-specific) and Part ‚ÄòB‚Äô (Aptitude).
  • Part ‚ÄòA‚Äô consists of 80 multiple-choice questions (MCQs) covering your core engineering curriculum.
  • Part ‚ÄòB‚Äô consists of 15 MCQs covering aptitude, numerical reasoning, etc.
  • Marking Scheme: +1 for a correct answer, -1/3 for an incorrect answer.
  • Qualifying Criteria: You need to score a minimum of 50% in Part A and Part B separately to be considered for shortlisting.

Stage 2: Interview

  • Based on the written test scores, candidates are shortlisted for an interview in a 1:5 ratio (for every one vacancy, five candidates are called).
  • The interview focuses on your theoretical knowledge and practical understanding of your engineering discipline.
  • The final selection is based solely on your performance in the interview. The written test is only for screening.
5. Final Words of Advice

Success in the ISRO exam requires a deep understanding of your engineering fundamentals. Focus on building a strong conceptual base rather than rote memorization. Good luck!

internship.title: Internships & Projects at ISRO
internship.html:
Your Launchpad to Space: A Complete Guide to ISRO Internships & Projects

1. Introduction: Go Beyond the Classroom üöÄ

The Indian Space Research Organisation (ISRO) opens its doors to ambitious students through its internship and project trainee programs. These are immersive experiences that allow you to work on cutting-edge space technology alongside the nation's top scientists and engineers.

2. Two Pathways to ISRO: Which One is for You?

A. The Internship Scheme

A short-term program (max 45 days) designed to give you a feel for the work culture and projects at ISRO. Ideal for gaining a quick, practical overview.

B. The Student Project Trainee Scheme

A longer, more intensive program where you can work on a specific academic project or dissertation. Duration varies from 45 days to over 30 months, depending on your degree.

3. Checking Your Eligibility: Do You Qualify? ‚úÖ

General Requirements for All Applicants

  • Citizenship: You must be an Indian citizen.
  • Academic Performance: Minimum aggregate of 60% or a CGPA of 6.32 on a 10-point scale.

Eligibility for the Student Project Trainee Scheme

DegreeEligibility CriteriaMax Duration
B.E./B.TechMust be in your final year.45 days
M.E./M.TechMust be in your final year.10-12 months
M.Sc.Must be in your final year.10-12 months
Ph.D.Must have completed at least 2 years of coursework.Up to 30 months
4. How to Apply: The Process ‚úçÔ∏è

Unlike other organizations, ISRO does not have a centralized online portal for internships. Applications must be sent via post through your institution.

  1. Your Head of Department (HOD) or Principal must forward your application.
  2. The application should include your academic records, CV, and a cover letter specifying your area of interest.
  3. Applications must be sent to the respective ISRO centre you wish to work at.
5. Important Notes

ISRO does not provide accommodation or a stipend for these programs. It's a learning opportunity, not a job. Due to high demand, it's best to apply well in advance.
